assessment.title: Function and Structure of the Integumentary System

p.em: How does the integumentary system contribute to immunity?

multiple_choice.choice: It feels when microorganisms are trying to enter.
It provides a physical barrier to most microorganisms.

response.feedback: Correct. The skin might actually be our most important immune organ because of this function.
Incorrect. That is the role of red bone marrow.
Not quite. The integumentary system does make us waterproof, but that is not an immune function.
Incorrect. Microorganisms are too small to activate receptors. However, the skin has immune cells located in the epidermis called Langerhans cells.

p.em: Which glands are most common in the skin?

response.feedback: Correct. We have merocrine sweat glands over most of our body to aid in the function of cooling when we get too hot. If you produce sweat on a region of your body, you have merocrine glands there.
Incorrect. These glands are located only on specific regions of your body, such as the genital and axillary (armpit) regions.
Not quite. Sebaceous glands secrete sebum (an oily material composed mostly of fat) to help keep our skin and hair moisturized, but they are not as common as certain sweat glands.
Incorrect. The skin doesn't include digestive glands.

part.hint: Most of our skin has glands that help with thermal regulation, but most areas do not secrete complex materials.
